div.p:
Mr Routledge
and a Mr Pardoe called
here yesterday morning
with the pamphlet,
I refused to look at it -
though they pretended
it was simply that
I might see that nothing
to my prejudice appeared
on the title page.

Routledge gave a broad
hint that he would
give something handsome
to the "Testimonial Fund"
if I would only give
him my countenance.
I replied. Satisfy Mr
Murray and you will
thereby satisfy me.

He said I have a
character to lose - to which
I merely said I don't
wish to hurt any one's
character but I have
abundant evidence that
people generally believe
this narrative is by me.
Now I have nothing to do
with. I knew nothing
about it". And left them
I did not ask them upstairs.

I saw the drawing
of Lake Ngami by the
poor young man who
died. It is very truthful
and good - the others
were better - the relatives
are on the trail of the
companion who kept
them to himself, as he has
removed from Keynsham
they have knowledge
of the frame maker who
was employed to mount
about 20 of them - Kolobeng
and another I could
identify. I am afraid
that if any stir is made
Stevenson the companion
will destroy the whole.

I have not yet got
Ford's address but
have got a bad cold
instead.
